without which

onegov pavel novikov
and myself all these guys have

i'll talk about vulnerabilities in
signaling protocols
so a few words about what signal
networks
are nowadays mobile networks use
three general signaling systems for
interoperation between operators
ss7 diameter and gtp
s7 is a set of protocols not just one
it is primarily intended to set up and
tear down telephone calls
later when mobile telephony appeared ss7
began to be used for subscriber mobility
roaming short messages and other
services
diameter is originally an altercation
authorization
and accounting protocol however this
protocol is extensible
rft 5516 is an example
of an extension this rfc defines
a set of common codes used in
applications for the evolved packed core
a world packet core is a switching
system of
lte networks gtp is a group of protocols
that were developed
to control packet data services on jsm
networks
however later gtp was adapted to work on
umts lte and even 5g networks with
non-standalone architecture signal
protocols are used between network
elements on operators infrastructure
not on the user side the basic unit in
signaling is a message
or a signal message this is like a
packet on ip networks
i will use the term message throughout
the presentation
please bear in mind that when i say
message
i mean not an sms message but a
signaling message
when an intruder gets access to the
signal network at any time compilator
that intruder can track locations
intercept
sms and voice calls performs denial of
service attacks on subscribers and home
networks
steal money from subscribers get
access to a mail social media mobile
messenger
apps and other applications intruders
are able to do
all these malicious actions against
any subscriber of any mobile operator
around the world
from any signaling connection
why are signal networks insecure when
the salem protocol stack
was developed nobody thought about
security
because ssl networks were originally
intended to support telephone calls only
they were assumed to be isolated from
other public networks
only a few large national telephone
providers would have access to ss7
but later mobile phones appeared the
number of players on the telephone
market rapidly increased
the number of users jumped and
consequently
the amount of signaling grew enormously
in the early 2000s a new specification
called sictron was introduced
sigtron allowed sending ss7 over ip
networks
so those two main assumptions underlying
signal security
were no longer true the number of
companies connected to
signal networks became huge and the
signal network
stopped being isolated new protocols
such as
diameter and gtp didn't solve security
either
in fact they brought new problems
fortunately mobile operators are aware
of the signaling security problem
and are trying to protect their networks
they implement signaling firewalls
sms home routine and signal ids systems
also mobile operators perform external
signal security assessments
however sometimes this is not enough
now i would like to describe the basic
identity and node types on mobile
networks
because i will also refer back to this
information
throughout the presentation the first
group of identities and nodes
is used on 2g and 3g networks such as

this identifier with a long acronym is
just the phone number
we will use to call our friends mc
international mobile subscriber identity
this is the identity of a sim card gt
a global title this is the main address
of the core
node on telecom networks that looks like
the
msa's then or telephone number the
gt and mss then have the same structure
network elements root signal message but
they are
gt and mss dense i should also note that
the mssdn
and mc are used in all mobile
generations
stp signal transfer point this is a
switch for signal traffic
usually the stp is a border point on a
mobile network
hlr home location register is a
subscriber database
of a mobile operator it contains the
following data
mssdn and emc identifiers of subscriber
allowed on prohibited services
addresses of not serving the subscriber
and
certain other data msc vlr
this is a single node that performs two
functions the msc mobile vision center
is a switch for voice and sms traffic
the vlr vista location register is a
database
of active subscribers that contains copy
of subscriber profiles from the hlr
plus some information from the radio
access system
such as the identity of the servant cell
as json theorem gprs support node this
node performs the same function that the
msc vlr does
but for packet data services and smsc
sms center this note handles sending and
delivery of short messages
gsm and umts networks rely on ss7
signaling
as i previously said ss7 is a stack of
protocols
i will highlight the most important
protocols in it from the security point
of view
the lowest layer that works on the
international level
is the sccp signal connection control
part
this protocol is responsible for global
routing of signaling messages
by telecom-specific identifiers which
are called global titles
the t-cup protocol is located above
the sccp this protocol combines single
requests and responses in two
dialogues and defines the context of the
upper layer application
the mobile application part or map is a
payload that contains a code of
a particular operation and relevant
parameters
mc location information profile data
and so on the second group of nodes is
used on 4g networks
such as lt d8 diameter edge agent
this is a switch for signal traffic
usually the da
is a border point on a mobile network it
works like an
stp but on diameter networks hss home
subscriber server
is a subscriber database of a mobile
operator
the hss is an evolution of the hlr
applicable
on lte networks mme mobile management
entity
supports mobility management procedures
for mobile subscribers
and is responsible for choosing the sgw
sgw serving gateway is a switch of user
data packets ims ip multimedia system
this is not an lte node but an
independent system
responsible for standardization of voice
calls on ip networks
ims is often used on lte networks as an
extension for voice call transmission
diameter the signal protocol for lte
networks
this protocol is ip based the transport
layer protocol
is sctp this protocol was developed
specially for telecom
applications finally the top layer
is diameter itself with a common code
application id and other parameters
gtp is a group of protocols it is
divided into
three protocols gtpc the control part is
used for signaling
gtpu the user part is used for tunneling
of
user data and gtp prime is used to
charge user traffic
as i previously said gtp is used on both
jsm umts and lte 5g networks
i also described sjsn and sgw nodes
ggsn and pgw are gateways between the
mobile operator
and external internet gtpc is also
an ip based protocol it utilizes udp as
a
transport the gtpc payload is located
just above udp
mobile networks have evolved these days
they combine several generations
so that mobile subscribers have seamless
service
the home subscriber databases are joined
mobile networks of new generations such
as
4 and 5g must have connectivity to
previous generation networks for this
purpose
iwf interworking function equipment is
used
it allows relaying ss7 messages to
diameter ones and vice versa
a mobile device on the combined networks
is connected simultaneously to
all possible generations when a mobile
device is
somehow disconnected from one of the
networks
it still remains online via other
network generations having performed
signal security audits since
2015 we have gathered interesting
statistics
in 2015 we didn't encounter any ssn
firewalls
in our audits in 2016 about
nine percent of networks had ssn
firewalls
in recent years we have seen ssn
firewalls becoming
more common and what about diameter
security
in 2015 audits we didn't encounter any
networks protected by a diameter
firewall
the same was true in 2016 and
in 20172 the first diameter firewalls in
our audience appeared
only in 2018 our protection of diameter
networks
is much worse than for ss7 networks
this is why intruders have focused on
diameter networks

that are feasible on mixed-generation
mobile networks
we have had the ability to recreate all
these attacks
in the wild during telecom security

the first case is voice call
interception or
meetum on a combined 2g 4g network
firstly i need to explain what a classic
medium attack on ss7 looks like
we assume that the intruder already
knows the emcee and address of the
serving msc
the attack consists of two steps in the
first step
the mail factor sends insult subscriber
data
to the msc vlr node in order to spoof a
billing platform
in the profile of the target subscriber
of course the main factor uses their
own address for the spoofed billing
platform
the msc vlr node just answers ok
and the mail factor finalizes the
transaction the
subscriber's profile is updated to
perform the second step of the attack
the mail factor should wait for the
subscriber to call
this call initiates a request to the
billing platform
that has been spoofed by the intruder at
the previous step
so the billing request in the initial dp
message
goes to the manufacturer's equipment
disclosing the numbers
of the subscribers involved in the call
the main factor sends a connect message
containing only one parameter
which is a number for call redirection
the intruder uses the number of their
own private branch exchange
the msc vlr obeys the command and
redirects the call to the intruder's pbx
then the intruder initiates the second
leg
of the call to the b subscriber spoofing
the number of the originating subscriber
they know information about the numbers
from the billing request
after that the call goes to the
appropriate subscriber and they are able
to talk
but what voice traffic goes through the
intruder's equipment
where they can record the call or listen
it
in real time and the same firewall can
protect the network against such
metim attacks when the hostile insert
subscriber data message
comes to the network the border stp
sends it to the ss7 firewall
the ss7 firewall sees the operation code
insert subscriber data
this is a category 2 operation meaning
that the
firewall has to check the source
operator
and the operator of the target
subscriber what we see
is a message sent from a swiss operator
but involving the subscriber from a
taiwanese operator
based on this result the ssn firewall
blocks the insert subscriber data
message
the network is protected when the
operator implements
voice over lte or volte the mme node
handles subscriber mobility and the ims
handles voice traffic
in this case even if the intruder
succeeds with the profile change in the
valuar database as the first step of the
midim attack
this does not affect voice calls via the
ims
as a result voiceover lte indirectly
protects the network
against many of the middle attacks
however our intruder is quite
experienced and has obtained access
to both the ss7 and diameter networks
during the first step
the intruder needs to suppress volte
for the subscriber they sends a cancel
location requesting
message on the diameter protocol this
message is intended to prohibit
subscriber services on the mme node
the mme implements the command and sends
a positive response to the source node
after that the tag subscriber is
automatically switched to the previous
generation network
previous generation network is based on
ss7 signaling
to explain the attack i have to talk
about
one interesting feature of the tcap
protocol
the component portion may contain more
than one map protocol
component in this case each map
component
defines its own operation and subscriber
identifiers in these operations
might be different when the ss7 firewall
inspects
such a double component message it
checks the subscriber's identity in the
first component
regarding the other data is a long
payload not meant to be inspected
let's see how the intruder can use a
double map component signaling message
to perform a man in the middle attack
they craft the double map message in
which the first operation
is insert subscriber data without a
subscriber identifier
and the second operation is delete
subscriber data
with the target subscriber mc the stp
sends this message to the ss7 firewall
which inspects the first component only
determines that
it does not have an identifier and
forwards the message to the destination
from the msc and vlr's point of view
these two operations don't make sense
the node has been asked to
simultaneously insert
and delete data in the subscriber's
profile
that's why the msc vlr replies with an
error message if we pay attention to the
details in this response
we find that the message type on the
pickup layer is continue
that means something like i don't

please repeat your request within the
same transaction
the intruder proceeds with the
transaction and sends
one more double map component message
the first component contains an insert
subscriber data operation without
subscriber identity information the
second one
also contains insert subscriber data
with the target subscriber mc
and spoofed address of the billing
system of course
this address belongs to the intruder's
equipment the ss7 firewall inspects the
first component only
after which it passes the message onto
the network
the msc vlr sends confirmation
for both operations that means the
subscriber's profile
has been updated the intruder now just
finalizes the transaction
now the intruder is waiting for the
subscriber to call
when the subscriber makes a call the msc
vlr sends the initial dp signal message
to the intruder's address
inserted earlier the intruder sends a

the msc redirects the call to the

after that the intruder redirects the

the subscribers have a conversation but

can see that
even sophisticated attacks like voice

are possible on well protected networks

the male factor will attack a modern 4g
5g

operation voice services become

when subscriber a calls target

the ims does not know where the call

that's why it sends location information

the intruder replies with the pbx

in location information answer message
after that the ims establish a call

pbx

to the hacker's ss7 node the request

let's look at two options for what an

in the first case the intruder sends an

on a fake 2g 3g roaming network

now subscriber b is without any kind of

for 5g mobile networks have an

this mme should restore the profile it

now the subscribers profile is restored

or 15. the main causes of
signal network issues are architectural
flaws
in the protocols mistakes in equipment
configuration
and sometimes software bugs
on the one hand most operators have
learned
to withstand ss7 flits connected
with the first two factors but
software bugs allow an intruder to
bypass security
on the other hand most operators are
still not protected
against diameter threats the thing is
that in most cases the mobile operator
can protect the network
better without extra costs they just
need to check
whether their security tools are
effective against new vulnerabilities
as soon as a new vulnerability is
reported we often see
that hackers use advanced techniques to
bypass
protection and perform attacks mobile
operators
are also advised to use a signal
intrusion detection system
along with a signaling firewall in order
to block a hostile source
as soon as a treat is detected operators
should configure their border security

to block all known vulnerabilities

should be implemented as a constant
